title-group.subtitle: Thin-Slicing Film to Illustrate Group Dynamics

author-notes.corresp: Mary J. Waller, York University, 4700 Keele St., Toronto, ON M4E3M1, Canada. Email: mwaller@yorku.ca

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue: Teaching People About Groups

abstract.p: The ability of group members to shape group behaviors can greatly influence collective outcomes; however, the skills associated with correctly recognizing behaviors in situ and responding appropriately to them on a real-time basis are typically not emphasized in group dynamics education. In this article, we describe a pedagogical method that uses film excerpts and a thin-slicing technique specifically designed to help students develop such skills. We identify a variety of sample film excerpts that illustrate several group behaviors—behaviors that recent research suggests can influence group effectiveness in different contexts. We end by discussing which group phenomena may or may not be particularly well-suited to this technique.

body.p: Given the reliance of countless organizations on both temporary and permanent groups (Lawler, Mohrman, & Ledford, 1992, 1995), the ability of group members and leaders to actively shape group behaviors and thereby improve group effectiveness plays a key role in organizational success. Related management, psychology, and communication education efforts typically involve teaching students fundamental group dynamics principles by using a combination of textbook reading, popular press articles, case studies, and group-based exercises. These efforts sometimes include using films such as Twelve Angry Men to illustrate and underscore important group behaviors (e.g., Armstrong & Berg, 2005; Hackley, 2007; McCambridge, 2003). In fact, the use of this particular film to illustrate group behavior has become so ubiquitous that (unscrupulous) students can visit numerous websites (see, for example, www.universitip.com) to find a variety of essays and term papers for sale—materials that carefully analyze aspects of group dynamics in the film.

The use of such films is relatively common in educational settings, and the ways in which they are used to teach group dynamics and other similar topics are fairly common as well. Often, students view an entire film and write an essay, either individually or as a group, focusing and reflecting on aspects of group dynamics (e.g., Buchanan & Huczynski, 2004; Smith, 2009) or group communication (e.g., Johnson & Iacobucci, 1995) portrayed in the film. Portions of films, are often used to illustrate specific group or organizational behaviors and generate discussion and/or writing topics about them (e.g., Armstrong & Berg, 2005; Tyler, Anderson, & Tyler, 2009). Entire films and film clips are also pedagogically useful in the discussion of many group-related topics including cultural awareness (Mallinger & Rossy, 2003), diversity (Bumpus, 2005), selection strategies (Billsberry & Gilbert, 2008), ethics (Berger & Pratt, 1998), mental illness (Wedding, Boyd, & Niemiec, 2009), and leadership (Rosser, 2007). Increased student receptiveness and positive student feedback (Billsberry & Gilbert, 2008; Mallinger & Rossy, 2003), as well as improved academic performance (Smith, 2009), have all been cited as outcomes of using film as a pedagogical tool.

We suggest here that the ability of individuals to recognize emerging group behavior on an immediate, real-time basis is also an important skill to develop, in addition to the more post hoc reflective or discussion-focused skills emphasized in most group dynamics education. In many organizational contexts, group members do not have the opportunity to think deeply or reflect on observed group behavior before taking action (or failing to do so). To appropriately leverage their knowledge of group dynamics theories, group members and leaders must be able to quickly recognize and categorize group behaviors in terms of appropriate theories or the emergent states that they may reflect and then take the immediate necessary action suggested by those theories. For example, on witnessing group conflict near the midpoint of a project, a group leader might appropriately choose not to intervene if she recognizes the conflict as a spirited discussion about key task decisions (see Gersick, 1989), but choose to intervene immediately if she recognizes the behavior as harmful relationship conflict (Jehn & Mannix, 2001). However, if the leader waits for hours or days to ponder what she saw and then address the harmful conflictual behavior, the opportunity to appropriately shape group behavior may be lost.

In our opinion, the ability to quickly recognize group behavior in situ, understand how that behavior maps onto fundamental group processes, and then take appropriate action all represent critical skills for students of group dynamics. However, discussion of the development of such skills is missing from the group dynamics textbooks we reviewed (i.e., Forsyth, 2009; Levi, 2010; Napier & Gershenfeld, 2003; Thompson, 2011) as well as from textbooks on organizational behavior (e.g., Colquitt, LePine, & Wesson, 2013; Mcshane, & Von Glinow, 2012; Robbins & Judge, 2010). We suggest that the recognition of group behavior in dynamic organizational settings is a specific ability that may be developed through the use of film as a pedagogical tool. In effect, this ability rests on the concept of thin slicing group behaviors—that is, the ability to recognize and correctly identify behaviors based only on thin slice of interaction (cf. Ambady & Rosenthal, 1992, 1993). Existing research provides evidence that individuals trained to recognize specific human behaviors, such as those involved in negotiations, can accurately do so using only very brief thin-sliced examples of real behavior (Curhan & Pentland, 2007). In this article, we suggest ways in which using multiple brief excerpts from films in rapid sequence can help students develop quick and accurate real-time recognition of group behaviors. Although the use of feature film in education is not a new idea (see Smith, 2009), it has garnered increasing attention in contemporary visual cultures. We believe that our specific use of film is particularly well-suited to illustrate the essence of group behavior. And as noted by Taylor and Ladkin (2009), film can reveal “depths and connections that more propositional and linear developmental orientations cannot” (p. 56).

sec.title: Behavior in Film
sec.p: We do not assume that all group behavior portrayed in film accurately portrays what happens in real groups. One would be hard pressed, for instance, to relate the behavior portrayed in some avant-garde films to any behavior likely to emerge in actual groups. But many films are realistic, portraying characters who are psychologically complex, adapt to different situations, and participate in social relationships (Langkjaer, 2011). Still, the methodology described here requires an instructor to use his or her knowledge of group dynamics to choose film clips that will portray the group behaviors of interest.

Scenes portraying group behavior in films typically differ from the experience of actual people in real groups: camera angles are used to show the facial expressions of multiple group members, group members typically do not speak simultaneously, events unfold relatively quickly, and characters’ emotions are often exaggerated. Notwithstanding these differences, however, audience members generally expect to see human behavior in film that they perceive as realistic (Hall & Bracken, 2011). For example, one particular exchange among three astronauts in the film Apollo 13 can be used to illustrate blame and lack of trust. The three astronauts involved in that exchange probably did not really speak to one another in such a clear manner, yet the behaviors and emotions involved in their exchange are veridical, based on historical accounts (Lovell & Kluger, 2006). In fact, some behaviors portrayed in film by individuals and groups are realistic enough to lead to the mimicking of the behaviors in reality; for example, depictions of suicide in film has been linked to actual suicide attempts in some cases (Jamieson & Romer, 2011).

sec.title: Teaching the Recognition of Group Behaviors
sec.p: The ability to notice and recognize or categorize others’ behaviors is important for human interaction. Processes such as attribution (Fiske & Taylor, 1984), stereotyping (Fiske, 1993), and modeling (Luthans & Kreitner, 1985) focus on individuals’ perceptions of the attributes and behaviors of others, and the subsequent actions taken on the basis of those perceptions. Moreover, people are likely to categorize the behaviors of others by assigning trait labels to those persons (Claeys, 1990). The existing work that pertains to individuals’ perceptions of groups rather than of individuals (e.g., Tajfel & Turner, 1979) tends to involve perceptions and categorizations based on group attributes and social categorization processes, rather than on noticing and categorizing specific group-level behaviors as they occur, and reacting to them. Taken together, this literature focuses on individuals’ perceptions, attributions, cognitions, and subsequent behaviors as they pertain to the noticed behavior of other individuals or to static group attributes that can be used to distinguish one group from another (see Ellemers, De Gilder, & Haslam, 2004). We suggest that for group members and leaders, perceptions and categorizations of group behaviors are also important because no one can hope to effectively use group dynamics theories to shape actual group dynamics in situ unless he or she can first learn to notice and appropriately recognize specific group behaviors.

The literature pertaining to social work education offers some direction in understanding how individuals (in this case, social workers) might be taught how to notice, correctly categorize, and react to behaviors in therapy groups. Although several articles have noted a steady decline in the emphasis on social group work in social work education and practice (see Birnbaum & Auerbach, 1994; Parry, 1991), those programs that still offer students training in group-work practice tend to combine class and experiential learning, with an emphasis on teaching students to connect theory with group practice (Gitterman, 1988). Work that focuses on developing the observational skills of students focuses on assisting students “in understanding that the group as a whole must be seen as the client . . . rather than looking at individual parts of behavior” (Clements, 2008, p. 332). Techniques used to develop students’ abilities to recognize and categorize group behaviors include using role-playing to imagine or reenact group behaviors, noticing and recording notes on actual group interactions as they occur, and modeling instructor interactions with a group (Clements, 2008). Other experiential techniques involve asking students to participate in groups themselves, and then (soon after) to reflect on both the dynamics of those groups and on their own personal behavior.

The group behaviors emphasized in social work education typically relate to issues such as phases of group development, norm development, nonverbal or latent cues, power and role distribution, and so on (Wayne & Cohen, 2001). Although social work education techniques suggest that students can be trained to reliably observe and categorize group processes, these techniques seldom emphasize the accurate recognition of more task-oriented group processes, which are important for groups. Many of the educational techniques used in social work also require that students engage in group observation and participation during fieldwork training over a period of several months, thereby exposing the students to processes that emerge over the life of a group. Social work education teaches students how to make appropriate real-time interventions, based on their observations and categorizations of group behaviors, including clarifying communication and confronting acting-out behavior in groups (Brandler & Roman, 1999). Overall, the literature on social work education indicates that students can indeed be taught to recognize and act on group behaviors, albeit after observing groups over a long period of time.

sec.title: A Thin-Slicing Technique
sec.p: The concept of thin-slicing has been a topic of inquiry in both the academic literature (e.g., Ambady & Rosenthal, 1993; Fowler, Lilienfeld, & Patrick, 2009) and the popular press (e.g., Gladwell, 2005). Research on the ability of individuals to accurately judge future outcomes from thin slices of behavior (typically video or audio-recorded clips) covers outcomes as diverse as negotiation agreements (Curhan & Pentland, 2007), college instructor ratings (Ambady & Rosenthal, 1993), and divorce (Gottman & Notarius, 2000). Typically, observers are shown a short video clip (ranging from seconds to a few minutes) of behavioral interaction (e.g., in a negotiating dyad) and are then asked to predict the outcome of the interaction based on the behavior observed. Pentland (2004, as cited in Curhan & Pentland, 2007) suggests that the signals used implicitly by observers of conversational dynamics to judge outcomes are activity (speaking time), engagement (turn-taking), emphasis (emotion), and mirroring (mimicking); all but emphasis are positively correlated with participants’ outcomes.

Thus, as previously discussed, the social work literature suggests that students can be taught to accurately recognize and act on group behaviors over the life of a group; the literature on thin-slicing suggests that observers can accurately extrapolate dyadic outcomes from very short segments of interpersonal interaction. We suggest that the integration of these two areas of evidence supports a pedagogical technique using thin-slicing of group interaction to teach students how to rapidly recognize specific group behaviors in real time. In practice, the thin-slicing technique can be used in the classroom after students have developed basic knowledge regarding principles of group dynamics via other pedagogical techniques, such as lecture, reading, discussion, and group exercises.

We have been using the thin-slicing technique for several years with MBA students in the full-semester course Managing Team Dynamics. For the approximately 25% of class meetings in which we use the technique, the first half of each class meeting focuses on an explication and discussion of a focal topic concerning team dynamics—for example, conflict. After a short break, the second half of class focuses on using the thin-slicing technique. For instance, after the first half of a class in which conflict types and their effects on team outcomes are discussed, we tell students to draw from course concepts to attend to the team behaviors in the clips they will be shown. We then show a short clip from Apollo 13, and ask students to say out loud what behaviors they see. Students keep track of their answers by noting them in a table on a simple paper handout. No discussion transpires at this point, and the instructor makes no comments. Students’ verbal responses are rapidly followed by the next clip—a scene from A Few Good Men. Again, students are asked to quickly name the type(s) of behaviors they see in the clip. Again, and rapidly, the third clip, drawn from the film The Departed, is shown, and students are once more asked to quickly identify the behaviors they saw. After these rapid viewings, the clips are shown again, one at a time, followed by a full discussion of the behaviors depicted in each clip. These discussions involve (a) matching the appropriate and previously discussed theory or research to the clip, (b) examining which answers during the thin-slicing exercise were more or less appropriate, (c) predicting what is likely to happen next in the team depicted in the clip, based on the behaviors discussed, and (d) analyzing what the appropriate action might be for the leader of the team depicted in the clip.

During each thin-slicing session, we suggest showing students a sequential string of three-to-five video clips of group interaction from multiple films, with clips up to approximately 120 s long. The difficulty of the exercise can be adjusted somewhat by the choice of clips used. For example, clips chosen from the same film and depicting the same characters would most likely facilitate recognition of behaviors, as would clips that only focus on one type of group behavior. In contrast, using clips drawn from multiple films that focus on a variety of group behaviors would most likely make the accurate recognition of the behaviors more difficult. Also, if students have already seen the film from which a clip is drawn, that might make it easier for them to remember details from the clip or to anticipate behaviors in the clip. However, the probability is low that students will have already categorized clip behaviors in terms of the group and team dynamics behaviors taught in their course. And because a variety of clips from different films are used in the exercise, there is little chance that any student will have seen all or even most of the clips.

By keeping the exercise fast-paced and oral, our technique approximates the real-time identification of group behaviors based on previously learned principles of group dynamics. Depending on the time available, multiple thin-slicing sessions can be held over multiple class meetings. The thin-slicing exercise can also be used in a pre- and postmanner by first showing students the film clips (as described above), then engaging in other discussion and exercises to develop students’ basic knowledge of group dynamics theories, and then finally engaging in the thin-slicing exercise again (using either the same or different clips) to illustrate how the students’ ability to recognize and react to group behaviors has changed. Instructors should be aware, though, that students occasionally identify behaviors in the clips that instructors have not anticipated, necessitating some flexibility in the discussion. In a recent class, for example, students viewed a clip from a film in which we expected them to see an example of reciprocal interdependence among group members (interdependence was a recent topic discussed in class). Instead, the students correctly identified the application of ideas contained in an assigned reading—Ericksen and Dyer’s (2004) suggestions for setting the tone of a new project team (by providing strategy and letting team members develop processes).

Our thin-slicing technique differs from the practice of showing students longer segments from films to illustrate a given group behavior or state. Rather than priming students by introducing a film clip as an example of some specific phenomenon (e.g., psychological safety), we generally use the technique without specific priming to facilitate the development of students’ own recognition skills. Priming may prove necessary, however, if students are not drawing adequately on course concepts in their descriptions of what they see. And rather than show and discuss just one film clip at a time, we prefer to show students a sequential string of clips in a dynamic, rapid-fire manner. This requires students to apply a variety of different group dynamics theories quickly and accurately. MBA students have reported to us that this “video batting practice” keeps them engaged in active participation, while offering the opportunity to apply what they have learned in a real-time setting. We currently have only anecdotal accounts from former students attesting to their improved ability to recognize group behaviors, but these accounts are compelling. Many of them come from semester-long team journals that individual students write as part of their course requirements. Unfortunately, these students were not asked (and thus did not agree) to allow their journal information to be used for the current article, so we cannot quote directly from their work. We are now in the process of collecting two types of data to evaluate the effects of our teaching method on students’ performance. First, we will specifically ask future students an open-ended question (to be answered in their journals) about the thin-slicing technique, and we will ask for permission to use their (anonymous) answers as part of our work. Second, several months after graduation, we will administer a self-report questionnaire to students who took the course, specifically asking whether they believe that the method has increased their ability to recognize behaviors in groups and teams in their current organizational settings.

To further facilitate the use of this pedagogical technique, a collection of film clips and corresponding group behaviors or emergent states is provided in Table 1. The behaviors and states were chosen based on previous research that identified key group behaviors and emergent states that significantly influence overall group outcomes (Kozlowski & Ilgen, 2006; Mathieu, Maynard, Rapp, & Gilson, 2008). All the clips noted involve interactions among at least three characters (cf. Moreland, 2010).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The use of film as a pedagogical tool has been discussed for some time, and the applications of film described in the literature range from using short clips as examples to supplement other material (Champoux, 1999; Kavan & Burne, 2009) to using film as the primary pedagogical medium (Smith, 2009). The technique we describe here employs thin-slicing to show students a series of very short film clips in rapid succession, requiring students to quickly identify group behavior and respond to it immediately. Because previous work indicates that individuals can accurately perceive and categorize others’ behavior by observing very brief samples of that behavior, we believe honing students’ skills in quickly assessing group behaviors will increase the probability that they will react to that behavior appropriately, either as group members or as group leaders. Although the reflective skills developed by asking students to view entire films and analyze them are undoubtedly useful as well, we believe the thin-slicing technique described here will add to students’ capabilities by sharpening their ability to recognize and manage group behavior on a more immediate basis.

Our thin-slicing technique focuses strictly on developing students’ abilities in recognizing and managing different types of group behaviors. For example, imagine a clip depicting a group engaged in shared leadership—no one member acts as leader, and the group engages in highly collaborative decision making or problem solving, with all members enacting some leader behaviors. This might have very positive implications if the group is involved in long-term innovative product design or very negative implications if the group is in a crisis situation and must make a fast decision. The technique suggested here focuses chiefly on developing students’ ability to identify a behavior and possibly to suggest subsequent actions they would take to increase or decrease this behavior. Extrapolating larger implications from the target behavior involves many other variables (e.g., context, goals) that instructors might choose to weave into their discussions.

In addition, our technique relies on the manifestation of group properties as observable behavior. In naturally occurring groups, however, brief glimpses of group behaviors do not always completely reflect emergent states that can influence behavior over the life of the group. For example, some aspects of shared cognition may influence behaviors of group members, but accurately evaluating something like mental model sharedness in a group, based on a very brief, thin slice of observable behavior, may not be possible. Similarly, the norms that motivate certain behaviors in groups may be quite stable, but behavioral observation of much longer duration than a thin slice may be needed to accurately derive information about group norms. Conversely, the overt and observable behaviors reflecting, for example, conflict, attention to time, helping behavior, uneven communication, subgroup formation, coaching, and in some cases, such emergent states as liking, trust, conformity, and mood, may be quickly and accurately identified using the thin-slicing technique.

Questions may arise regarding our choice to rely on clips from films rather than videos gathered from actual work teams or from students engaging in group-level simulations or role-playing. Three factors motivated this choice. First, and as noted previously, the scripting, acting, direction, editing, and sound that are used to portray group-level behaviors in film tend to ignore some elements of natural conversation, such as simultaneous conversation, or unintelligible utterances, that would significantly increase the difficulty for inexperienced students attempting to identify group behaviors. Although viewing naturally occurring group conversation might be more realistic, the clarity of group behaviors represented in film makes film clips more appropriate as an initial instructional technique (Champoux, 1999). Second, the behaviors portrayed in films tend to be more physically demonstrative and dramatic than the behavior of people in actual groups, and so film behavior is more easily identified than the behaviors engaged in by people in real groups. Once again, this makes the group-level behaviors in film clips easier to identify by inexperienced students (Hassard & Holliday, 1998). Third, using defined segments from easily obtained film facilitates both out-of-classroom work on thin-slicing by students as well as possible collaborative thin-slicing pedagogical research across courses, universities, and researchers.

In sum, film has been used to depict individual and group behavior in classroom settings for some time, and several resources exist to facilitate using entire films or extended portions of films to illustrate specific group behaviors and to motivate discussion and reflection. We suggest here that the technique of thin slicing film clips and showing them to students in rapid succession will help students to develop the skill of real-time recognition of group-level behaviors—a skill necessary in the fast-paced, dynamic environments faced by many groups today. We see this skill as complementary to other discussion- or reflection-oriented techniques, rather than as a substitute, and we believe that using film in a variety of ways in the classroom will both engage students and prepare them to become more effective group members and leaders.

bio.title: Author Biographies
bio.p: Mary J. Waller (PhD, University of Texas at Austin) is professor of organization studies at the Schulich School of Business, York University, Toronto, Canada. She conducts research focused on team dynamics and effectiveness particularly during nonroutine or crisis situations. Her work appears in management and psychology academic journals and volumes.

Golchehreh Sohrab is a PhD candidate in organization studies at the Schulich School of Business, York University, Toronto, Canada. In her research, she explores team dynamics in uncertain, dynamic, and complex environmental conditions and seeks to understand behaviors and processes that enable teams to successfully adapt to nonroutine situations.

Bernard W. Ma is a business consultant for a major Canadian bank. He completed his MBA at the Schulich School of Business, York University, Toronto, Canada, with a focus in organizational studies. Prior to his MBA, he was a software developer with a computer engineering degree from the University of Toronto.
